articles.headline: Republicans Try to Fix Damage Scalise’s 2002 Speech Could Do in 2016
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner issued a statement supporting Steve Scalise of Louisiana, the No. 3 Republican in the House, who confirmed that in 2002 he addressed a group of white supremacists.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner issued a statement supporting Steve Scalise of Louisiana, the No. 3 Republican in the House, who confirmed that in 2002 he addressed a group of white supremacists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders, poised for a celebratory takeover of Congress next week, instead found themselves scrambling Tuesday to defuse a racially charged controversy over one lawmaker’s speech a decade ago to a white supremacist group.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Auto Industry Galvanized After Record Recall Year
articles.snippet: Spurred by an ignition switch defect in millions of General Motors vehicles, the auto industry has issued more recalls involving old models than ever before, an analysis shows.
articles.abstract: Spurred by an ignition switch defect in millions of General Motors vehicles, the auto industry has issued more recalls involving old models than ever before, an analysis shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Spurred by a decade-old ignition-switch defect in millions of General Motors vehicles, the auto industry this year has issued more recalls involving old models — those made five or more years ago — than ever before, an analysis of federal recall records by The New York Times shows.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Hilary Stout

articles.headline: As Lithuania Joins Eurozone, Relief and Hesitation
articles.snippet: In the new year, the country becomes the 19th nation to adopt the euro, and the likelihood of economic and geopolitical security looms large for many.
articles.abstract: In the new year, the country becomes the 19th nation to adopt the euro, and the likelihood of economic and geopolitical security looms large for many.
articles.lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — If anyone still has good reasons for joining the euro, it is the people bundled against the cold of this snow-dusted capital.

articles.headline: A Veteran’s Chemical Burns Expanded Military Doctors’ Knowledge, but His Care Faltered
articles.snippet: An Air Force staff sergeant’s injuries from a chemical round led the Army to urge lifelong monitoring of such cases, but he says he was not tracked after retiring.
articles.abstract: An Air Force staff sergeant’s injuries from a chemical round led the Army to urge lifelong monitoring of such cases, but he says he was not tracked after retiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: LORDS VALLEY, Pa. — Daniel Mould’s sense of abandonment was profound.

articles.headline: Kings Theater in Flatbush Set to Reopen, and Lift a Neighborhood
articles.snippet: The 1920s movie theater, soon to reopen as a performing arts center, is already stimulating development in its neighborhood.
articles.abstract: The 1920s movie theater, soon to reopen as a performing arts center, is already stimulating development in its neighborhood.
articles.lead_paragraph: A jewel of the golden age of the New York City movie theater is being revived, with the reopening in February of the former Loews Kings Theater on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn.

articles.headline: Norwegians Turn Ambivalent on Statoil, Their Economic Bedrock
articles.snippet: Though oil and gas provide a quarter of Norway’s G.D.P., concern over climate change is fracturing the country’s bond with its flagship company.
articles.abstract: Though oil and gas provide a quarter of Norway’s G.D.P., concern over climate change is fracturing the country’s bond with its flagship company.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO — This has not been a particularly good year for Statoil, the huge state-controlled oil company that has had a commanding presence in Norway’s economy and society for more than four decades.

articles.headline: Obama’s Trade Chief, Undaunted by Odds, Pushes for Trans-Pacific Partnership
articles.snippet: Michael Froman, the United States trade representative, is confident he can persuade Congress to approve a long-pending agreement that encompasses 12 countries.
articles.abstract: Michael Froman, the United States trade representative, is confident he can persuade Congress to approve a long-pending agreement that encompasses 12 countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Michael B. Froman, President Obama’s chief evangelist for expanding global trade, skepticism comes with the territory.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Sony Cyberattack, First a Nuisance, Swiftly Grew Into a Firestorm
articles.snippet: Interviews suggest that Sony — slow to realize the depths of its peril — let its troubles deepen by mounting a public defense only after enormous damage had been done.
articles.abstract: Interviews suggest that Sony — slow to realize the depths of its peril — let its troubles deepen by mounting a public defense only after enormous damage had been done.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was three days before Thanksgiving, the beginning of a quiet week for Sony Pictures. But Michael Lynton, the studio’s chief executive, was nonetheless driving his Volkswagen GTI toward Sony’s lot at 6 a.m. Final planning for corporate meetings in Tokyo was on his agenda — at least until his cellphone rang.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Start-Ups Rise to Close a Gap for Farmers
articles.snippet: Small businesses are stepping in to help farmers connect with their local markets with marketing, transportation, logistics and other services.
articles.abstract: Small businesses are stepping in to help farmers connect with their local markets with marketing, transportation, logistics and other services.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLESLEY, Mass. — In spite of the surging demand for locally and regionally grown foods over the last few years, there is a chasm separating small and midsize farmers from their local markets.

articles.headline: How Putin Forged a Pipeline Deal That Derailed
articles.snippet: Russia’s energy minister and its energy giant, Gazprom, helped shape a Bulgarian bill for a pipeline that President Vladimir V. Putin sought to keep Europe dependent on Russian gas.
articles.abstract: Russia’s energy minister and its energy giant, Gazprom, helped shape a Bulgarian bill for a pipeline that President Vladimir V. Putin sought to keep Europe dependent on Russian gas.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Barely two weeks after President Vladimir V. Putin annexed Crimea on one side of the Black Sea, he won a different prize on the other side. In Bulgaria’s Parliament, lawmakers gave initial passage to a bill clearing the way for a mammoth gas pipeline from Russia.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Huge Ski Resort for the Rich Is Bouncing Back
articles.snippet: Today, six years after its bankruptcy, the Yellowstone Club is thriving.
articles.abstract: Today, six years after its bankruptcy, the Yellowstone Club is thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIG SKY, Mont. — In the weeks before the holiday season, snowfall at the Yellowstone Club is both a blessing and a curse.

articles.headline: Crash of AirAsia Flight 8501 Spotlights Indonesia’s Poor Air Safety Record
articles.snippet: There are renewed concerns that Indonesia cannot keep up with the growing popularity of air travel as incomes rise and low-cost carriers multiply.
articles.abstract: There are renewed concerns that Indonesia cannot keep up with the growing popularity of air travel as incomes rise and low-cost carriers multiply.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When a team of United Nations auditors visited Jakarta in May to rate the country’s aviation safety, they came to a troubling conclusion: Indonesia was well below the global average in every category, and scored just 61 percent in airworthiness.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Keith Bradsher
